FUJIFILM Holdings (FUJIY  -  Free Report) continues to focus on rapid expansion of its footprint in the fast growing healthcare sector.Apart from investments in developing research & development (R&D) infrastructure and partnerships, the company is also making strategic acquisitions. These buyouts are expected to drive growth in the healthcare market.FUJIFILM recently announced the buyouts of Irvine Scientific Sales (ISUS) and IS JAPAN (ISJ), both subsidiaries of JXTG Holdings Inc., for almost $800 million. The acquisition expands its product portfolio in the cell culture media market, which is projected to grow 10% annually.We note that strong growth in the Imaging Solutions (19.8% of total revenues) and Information Solutions (39.8% of total revenues) segments has been the primary growth driver in the last reported quarter.Information Solutions segment increased 12.3% year over year, primarily driven by stronger medical systems and electronic materials businesses. We believe the expanding product portfolio will boost company’s market share in the healthcare market, consequently driving top-line growth.FUJIFILM has returned 2.3% in the past year, compared with the industry’s decline of 21.8%. Acquisitions Expand Cell Culture Media OfferingBoth ISUS and ISJ are well-known providers of cell culture media, which is essential for cell culturing in the R&D and manufacturing of biopharmaceuticals and regenerative medicine products.Notably, FUJIFILM acquired Wako Pure Chemical Industries, a leading reagent manufacturer, in April 2017, to enter the cell culture media market. The company has also acquired Cellular Dynamics International, biotechnology firm, to expand its healthcare offerings.Cell culture media market is anticipated to grow on solid demand for biopharmaceuticals that are focused on antibody drugs and the increasing need for treatments using cells.The latest acquisitions will aid FUJIFILM to offer products for biopharmaceutical production, in vitro fertilization and cell therapy. Moreover, the buyout will increase the company’s distribution capabilities in the United States and Europe.Healthcare Offers Strong Growth OpportunitiesFUJIFILM has also forged partnerships to solidify its position in the healthcare market. Recently, the company collaborated with Takeda Pharmaceutical for inventing newfangled regenerative medicine therapies for the treatment of heart failure.FUJIFILM is also set to invest ¥4 billion in the pharmaceutical manufacturing site of its group company, Toyama Chemical. Moreover, the company is launching the Bio-Science & Technology Development Center for conducting R&D activities for its biopharmaceuticals business.Xerox Deal Remains an OverhangIn January 2018, FUJIFILM and Xerox Corporation (XRX  -  Free Report) inked a definitive deal worth $6.1 billion to combine the FujiXerox joint venture with Xerox. Per the deal, Fujifilm will own 50.1% shares of Fuji Xerox that will continue to trade with the same name on the NYSE.However, the deal has been heavily criticised by activist investors — Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason — who own more than 10% of Xerox. Both the investors believe that the deal significantly undervalues Xerox.The expected proxy fight between FUJIFILM and activist investors is likely to hurt share price momentum at least in the near term.Zacks Rank & Stocks to ConsiderFUJIFILM has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).NVIDIA (NVDA  -  Free Report) and Micron (MU  -  Free Report) are stocks worth considering in the broader technology sector. Both sport Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.Long-term earnings growth rate for NVIDIA and Micron is currently pegged at 10.25% and 10%, respectively.Can Hackers Put Money INTO Your Portfolio? Is the Earnings Improvement for Real?

The Finance sector gave us a good start to the 2014 Q2 earnings season. It isn’t ‘good’ in terms of growth – there is not much of that for the big banks and brokers. There weren’t many surprises on the net interest margins, trading volumes, and mortgage business fronts – they have been weak for a while and we saw more of that in Q2 as well. What came as a pleasant surprise were signs of modest improvement in lending and investment banking.

These improvements coupled with tight cost controls resulted in better than expected result for the Finance sector. As the charts below ‘beat ratios’ for the sector shows, the 42% of the sector’s market capitalization that have reported Q2 results are overwhelming coming out with positive surprises.

With results from the big banks and brokers now behind us, attention in the sector will shift to the insurance industry which will start reporting this week. Overall, total earnings for the Finance sector companies that have reported are essentially flat (up only +0.2%) on modestly lower revenues (down -0.6%).

The composite (or blended) Q2 picture for the sector, combining the actual results for the 17 companies that have reported with estimates for the still-to-report 63 companies, is for earnings growth of +2.9%. This is better than pre-season estimates and the sector’s Q1 performance when earnings were down -7.1% from the same period last year. Hopes remain high that the sector will resume its growth trajectory in the coming quarters, as the chart below shows.
These growth projections reflect aggressive estimates for the sector, but the strong results thus far in Q2 has likely increased confidence in these estimates.Earnings Calendar (week of July 21)

Next week’s reporting calendar (the week of July 21) takes us into the heart of the Q2 earnings season this week with almost 600 companies reporting results, including 141 S&P 500 members. This week’s line-up of reports spans the entire breadth of the U.S. economy – from Apple (AAPL) and Facebook (FB) to Coke (KO), Ford (F), Verizon (VZ  -  Free Report) and a lot more in the middle.

With a little over a tenth of the Q2 results already in, we can say that the reporting season is off to a good start. By the end of next week, we will know definitively how good this earnings season has been.The Scorecard Thus Far (as of Thursday evening, July 17th)

Total earnings for the 73 S&P 500 members that have reported results are up +5.5% from the same period last year, with a ‘beat ratio’ of 68.5% and a median surprise of +3.5%. Total revenues are up +3.8%, with a revenue ‘beat ratio’ of 50.7% and a median surprise of 1.4%.

In terms of growth rates and beat ratios, this is better performance than what this same group of 73 companies reported in Q1. The performance thus far even compares favorably with the 4-quarter average, as the chart below shows.  The grorwth rate compared
The beat ratios compared Expectations for 2014 Q2

The composite (or blended) growth picture for Q2, combining the actual results for the 73 companies that have reported with estimates for the 427 still-to-come reports, shows total earnings increasing by +4.8% on +2.2% higher revenues and modestly higher net margins. This would follow earnings growth of +0.8% in Q1 on +0.7% higher revenues. The Q2 earnings growth rate is steadily going up, as more companies report and beat estimates.
The table below compares what is expected for Q2 with what was actually achieved in Q1.

In-line with the pattern that has been in place for almost two years now, estimates for Q2 fell in the run up to the start of the reporting cycle. But the magnitude of negative revisions was low relative to other recent quarters. With the reporting cycle getting into high gear in the coming days following a good-enough start, the focus will be on how companies guide towards the current and coming quarters on the earnings calls.

Guidance has been mixed thus far, but commentary along the lines of what we heard from Intel (INTC), Sherwin-Williams (SHW  -  Free Report) and a few others will raise greater confidence in the aggregate estimates for Q3 and beyond.
The chart below shows consensus earnings growth expectations for the coming quarters.

Corporate guidance, which has persistently been on the weak side in recent quarters, will determine whether those expectations will hold or will need to come down.For a detailed look at the earnings picture, please check out our weekly Earnings Tends report.Monday-7/21

Not much on the economic calendar, but almost 50 companies will be reporting Q2 results (9 S&P 500 members).Halliburton (HAL) and Manpower (MAN  -  Free Report) are the notable reports in the morning, while Chipotle (CMG) and Netflix (NFLX  -  Free Report) will report after the close.
Zacks Earnings ESP or Expected Surprise Prediction, our proprietary leading indicator of positive earnings surprises, is showing Chipotle coming out with an earnings beat.
Our research shows that companies with positive ESP and Zacks Rank of 1, 2 or 3 are highly likely to beat earnings estimates. Chipotle currently has Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) and Earnings ESP of +1.0%.
For more details about Earnings ESP, please check this page.  Tuesday -7/22
We will get the June CPI and Existing Home Sales numbers, with expectations of strong gains in the home sales numbers.

A busy day on the earnings calendar, with more than 100 companies reporting results, including 36 S&P 500 members.Verizon (VZ  -  Free Report), DuPont (DD), Coke (KO), McDonalds (MCD  -  Free Report) and Travelers (TRV  -  Free Report) are some of the major companies reporting in the morning, while Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT  -  Free Report) will report after the close.

Earnings ESP is showing Coke and McDonalds coming out with positive earnings surprises. McDonalds has Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) and positive ESP of +0.7%, while Coke has Earnings ESP of +4.8% and Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Wednesday-7/23

Nothing on the economic calendar, but a very day on the earnings side, with more than 150 companies reporting Q2 results (37 S&P 500 members)Boeing (BA), Pepsi (PEP  -  Free Report) and Delta Airlines (DAL) are the key reports in the morning, while Facebook (FB) will be the highlight after the close.
Boeing, with an Earnings ESP of +1% and Zacks Rank of 3, is expected to come out with a positive earnings surprise.Thursday -7/24
In addition to weekly Jobless Claims data, we will get the June New Home Sales numbers. The expectation is for New Home sales to decline from May’s 504K level.

We have the busiest day of the Q2 earnings season thus far, with 237 companies reporting results, including 50 S&P 500 members.Ford (F), GM (GM), Caterpillar (CAT), Southwest (LUV), and 3M (MMM  -  Free Report) are some of the notable companies reporting in the morning, while Amazon (AMZN), Starbucks (SBUX  -  Free Report) and Pandora (P  -  Free Report) will report after the close.
Earnings ESP is predicting positive surprises from Southwest Airlines, Caterpillar, Ford, and 3M.
Southwest has Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) and Earnings ESP of +3.4%; Caterpillar has Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) and Earnings ESP of +3.3%, while #3 Ranked Ford has Earnings ESP of +2.7%.Friday-7/25
The June Durable Goods Orders will be coming out in the morning, with expectations of +0.3% ‘headline’ increase after the -0.9% decline the month before.

The market will likely get a lift from a number of positive earnings announcements today, even as it waits for the European deal on Wednesday. Stocks did not take a negative view of the inconclusive weekend Euro-zone summit, but it may not be as charitable if faced with another delay.

The market appears to have priced in some sort of a viable European plan and fresh doubts on that front will likely put a stop to the current market rally. Stocks have made impressive gains this month, up almost 14% since October 3, on rising European hopes and the reassuringly strong quarterly earnings reports.

A number of this morning's earnings reports were particularly reassuring. DuPont (DD) handily beat earnings and revenue expectations and guided higher. UPS (UPS  -  Free Report) came out with a positive earnings surprise on in-line revenue and reiterated its earlier guidance. Xerox (XRX  -  Free Report) also came ahead of earnings and revenue expectations and reiterated its guidance. 3M (MMM  -  Free Report) missed expectations and guided lower on weakness in its electronics business, citing economic factors.Texas Instruments (TXN  -  Free Report) came short of expectations after the close on Monday, citing economic headwinds, and guided lower. Netflix (NFLX  -  Free Report) shares will be in the spotlight for the wrong reasons as the company provided downbeat guidance even as it came ahead of expectations in its quarterly results.

Contrary to some of the more exaggerated concerns about earnings outlooks, the overall tone of earnings reports in this cycle has been positive. Xerox Corp. (XRX  -  Free Report) pleased investors with its earnings release last week. Covering analysts continue to raise estimates making shares of XRX an even better value.
Company Description

Xerox Corp is well known for its copy, printer and multi-functional machines as well as software solutions to improve business productivity. The company also sells paper and network integration products.
Another Surprise
Xerox just announced quarterly results on Jan 21 that showed earnings per shares of 25 cents, 3 cents better than analysts expected. This marked the company's fourth consecutive earnings surprise.
Revenues dipped slightly to $4.2 billion, but Xerox's continued efforts to streamline its business model leaves it well positioned for an economic turnaround.
Estimates Rising

Analysts have submitted 11 upward revisions for full-year fiscal 2010 since the earnings release. The Zacks Consensus is now 79 cents, up from 73 cents. Next year's forecasts are coming in at 99 cents, up from 94 cents.
If these levels are met, Xerox's earnings growth rates will be 32% and 25%, respectively.
Valuation
Currently, shares of XRX are trading at 11 times forward earnings. Xerox's price to sales ratio is about 0.5 times.
The Chart
Investors loved the earnings news, but the broader sell off weighed on the stock giving it an even better value. Take a look at the chart below.

Document equipment giant Xerox (XRX  -  Free Report) sees its current Average Broker Rating (ABR) rise to 2.5  up 0.25 from the previous week.  A recently announced near-$100 million contract agreement with the U.S. Navy, as well as a strategic buyout the previous month, have helped buoy the companys average rating.

According to our Zacks Research Digest analysts, Xerox maintains its market dominance in the production segment, though one analyst sees increased competition in the future as other industry players are attracted to the higher margins and more robust annuity revenue streams that follow placement of high-end devices.  Most analysts believe the color devices business remains an area of concern, as ongoing commoditization at the lower end and the anticipated emergence of new entrants will accelerate pricing pressure that has been plaguing the industry increasingly up the hardware value chain.

Furthermore, the average selling price of certain products could come under pressure as less expensive printer-based technology is adopted, without enough corresponding unit growth to sustain current revenue levels.  The annuity stream flow of revenue stemming from service and parts (for current A3 devices) could atrophy as devices become inexpensive, making service contracts no longer economically appealing.
Other Large-Cap Stocks Recently Upgraded Include:

Oft-embattled tobacco behemoth Altria Group (MO) was another big gainer in ABR, up 0.11 to an even 2.  This, despite potentially damaging litigation risks, which continually persist (though they are moderating substantially).

Zacks Research Digest analysts earnings growth forecast over the next three to five years range from 6.0% to 8.0%, with the average being 7.0%. Market share in the U.S. and Western Europe has stabilized after several quarters of real volume decline in the U.S. and severe competition in Europe.  Promotions continue, particularly in Europe, but MO chose to offer a new cigarette at the low end in Germany rather than discount Marlboro there.  The analysts state that while non-U.S. and European markets offer the most growth potential, the company may have to contend with the fact that emerging markets may not be those from which the highest margins can be obtained.

Chicago area-based Walgreens (WAG) improvement in ABR  to 2.47 after an 0.07 increase  was likely influenced by the companys proposals for growth. WAG expects to open 550 new stores in FY08, with a net increase of more than 475 stores after relocations and closings. By the year 2010, it plans to have 7,000 drugstores in operation.

Our Research Digest analysts state that the presence of positive drivers in the drugstore industry mainly driven by solid Rx share growth  and growing generic penetration and contribution from Medicare Part D should benefit the industry as a whole.  Specific to Walgreen Company itself, despite rapid store expansion plans, it generates positive free cash flow, and has a pristine balance sheet with zero debt.

Finally, new drug-eluting stents and a new spinal fixation system may have assisted Medtronic, Inc.s (MDT) rise in ABR from 1.84 to 1.89.  A leader in the cardiology industry, MDT has a strong balance sheet with manageable debt and a high cash balance.

Research Digest analysts report that management at Medtronic has reiterated that it can achieve long-term EPS growth of 15% without acquisitions.  It has the resources to make investments into any area of the medical device and medical technology industry.  The Digest average long-term growth rate is 13.9%, ranging between a low of 11.0% and a high of 16.0%.
